posts.cooked: My team was thinking about purchasing this servo ( https://www.actuonix.com/T16-R-Mini-Track-Actuator-with-Servo-Control-300mm-221-12-volts-_p_463.html ) to move an extension outside of out perimeter. From what we found it should be legal but I wanted to double check on here that it really is legal.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
I think you need to read R501 more closely. This appears to not be a “ PWM servo”, which would be allowed under certain conditions. Because it is not a PWM servo, it MUST use a motor that is legal under R501 … which it almost certainly does not as-purchased. You would need to fit an FRC -legal motor to it.

I believe REV sells a linear actuator kit that would do a similar job once fitted with an FRC -legal motor (which it includes mounting hardware for).

posts.name: Alex Weiss
posts.cooked: From page 88 from the game manual “ PWM COTS linear servos with max stall current ≤ 1A at 6V”. I am unsure if that is a PWM device(I don’t think it is, and is not allowed if it’s not) but its technical specifications are rated <1A at 12 V which is not a allowed specification.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked:
Wcp sells a very similar servo, and is controlled by pwm. (and only 6 volts)

These nifty little linear servos act like pneumatic air cylinders, but are powered by an electronic servo instead of compressed air! This means that not only do they provide reliable linear motion, but also have the added bonus of being able to...

Price: USD 69.99

This appears to be the correct document describing the pinout of the servo and how to control it. If it really is the right one, then this is not a legal servo, for the reasons @EricH described.

This is a motor with a potentiometer feedback cable, and the motor inside is not on the list of allowed motors. The separately-sold controller board has a PWM input, but it is a standalone motor controller, and not on the list of allowed motor controllers.
